awd_titl_txt: SODA Conference Student and Postdoc Travel Support
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports student and postdoctoral fellow attendance at the
SIAM-ACM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms (SODA), to take place during
January 9-10, 2022 in Alexandria, Virginia. SODA is one of the few
major conferences with broad coverage of Theory of Computing and
Discrete Mathematics. SODA has a record of strongly encouraging
participation by students, for whom the conference serves as a valuable
educational experience, both for the technical content of the talks and
for the opportunities for networking that it provides. This award will
provide partial support to about 20 students/postdocs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this grant, written in my role as the Chair of ACM-SIAM SODA Steering Committee is to assist students/postdocsto attend the 2022 Annual ACM-SIAM SODA Conference. The goal is to encourage andenable the participation of students/postdocs incases where travel expenses would otherwise preclude their attendance. With priority given to support young scholars from under-representedgroups, broadening the participation will benefit students in need as well as strengthen the long-term robustness and diversity of this top conference in Theoretical Computer Sciece.

We received $15,000 from NSF for SODA 2022. However, after planning an in-person SODA  (lead by SIAM), the Omicron Spike then canceled the in-person conference less than two months prior and made it a virtual SODA for the second year in a row. Because SODA was forced to be a virtual conference, the conference organizers worked hard to reduce students’ registration fees. As theresult, this SODA'22 NSF Travel Account had abalance of $7,196, after supporting the registrations of 10 students. After discussing with the NSFprogram directors, and the in-coming SODA Steering chair, Professor Piotr Indyk of MIT, we transfer this remining fund to SODA 2023. 

It has been a wonderful experience interactingwith many talented young researchers in TCS andtheir advisors in many universities to understandtheir excitement about the research fields andtheir needs. I hope these experiences willcontribute to future collaboration between NSFand TCS conferences, particular in areas ofsupporting NSF's goals for recruiting a diversespectrum of participants.

Intellectual Merit:

With the rise of Internet and Big Data, computerscience is now at the center of the manydisciplines, from natural sciences to socialsciences, from medicine to art, from engineeringto policy. As these interactions emerging,theoretical computer scientists, particularly theyounger generation, have taking great strides inadvancing algorithmic/computational thinkingbeyond our traditional field. The NSF travel awardhave been making direct contribution to thisgeneration.

ACM-SIAM SODA is the premier TCS conference on algorithms design and its underlying discrete mathematics. It has a long standing that has continued to play a formative role in the field; itis also at the leading edge of connections madeto other fields. For SODA 2022 and the subsequent, we were able to use this NSF grant to support or partly support 19 students. 

We believe that the resultant discussions willexpose the awardees to a broad set offundamental questions and ideas. With strongaim to support young research from underrepresented groups and talented students beyond traditional TCS powerhouses,our goal is to broaden the participation to make SODA an even more robust TCS conference. We expect the research community to benefit in turn, as such junior researchers have contributed substantially to the growth of theoretical computer science over the years. 

Broader Impacts:

Build on the NSF SODA travel grants, we also applied and received some industry support for our students. Working with TCS Women, we provided FULL support to several women applicants. By supporting applicants from more than 14 universities, the funds were widely distributed among many universities beyond just traditionalTCS power houses. Working with NSF and young researchers in this selection process provided us valuable experienceto be more proactive in reaching out to TCS Women community/organizations to encourage female theoretical computer scientists about future NSF SODA travel grants. 

Many of the Ph.D. students  supportedby NSF SODA travel grants will be future leaders in computer science. Several have already made breakthrough discovery in algorithm design andcomputational complexity by solving long-term fundamental open questions. The NSF travelaw ard, particular at this stage of their professional career, are critical support to their growth. In addition to help them to participate the premier conferences to benefit them and the research community, the application process also helped them to recognize how much their research are supported by not just their advisors/institutes, but by society in large.
